facts.text: Three petitioners are residents of Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The three Petitioners who are residents of Amritsar have filed this Petition under Art. 3 2 of the Constitution

facts.text: First petitioner carries on a bakery business in a shop in Bazar Jallianwala near Chowk Phowara as tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The first Petitioner carries on a Bakery business in a shop in Bazar Jallianwala near Chowk Phowara of which he is a tenant.

facts.text: Second petitioner is owner of a building consisting of shops in Bazar Bikanarian.

anchor.surface_text: The second Petitioner is the owner of a building companysisting of a number of shops situated in Bazar Bikanarian

facts.text: Third petitioner is tenant in occupation of a residential house in Bazar Sodhian.

anchor.surface_text: while the third Petitioner is a tenant in occupation of a residential house situated in Bazar Sodhian.

facts.text: State Government declared entire area within walled city of Amritsar as damaged area by notification under Sec. 2(d) on 26th June 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On 26th June 1962 the State Govt. declared by a Notification under Sec. 2 d  of the Act the entire area within the walled city of Amritsar to be a damaged area.

facts.text: Improvement Trust of Amritsar formulated schemes including Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh and Ghantaghar.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the said Notification a number of schemes were formulated by the Improvement Trust of Amritsar. Two of such Schemes with which the Petitioners are companycerned related to   1   Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh and  2  Ghantaghar.

facts.text: Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh Scheme sanctioned by State Government notification on 17th July 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The former Scheme was sanctioned by the State Govt., by a Notification dated the 17th July 1968, while the Ghantaghar Scheme was sanctioned by Notification of the 10th October 1969.

facts.text: Ghantaghar Scheme sanctioned by notification on 10th October 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The former Scheme was sanctioned by the State Govt., by a Notification dated the 17th July 1968, while the Ghantaghar Scheme was sanctioned by Notification of the 10th October 1969.

facts.text: Notice issued on 26th November 1969 to first petitioner to vacate premises covered by Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to these Notifications a Notice was issued on 26th November 1969 to the first Petitioner whose shop is companyered by the Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh Scheme to vacate the premises in his possession.

facts.text: Notices given to petitioners 2 and 3 to appear before Land Acquisition Collector (3rd respondent) regarding Ghantaghar Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice was also given to Petitioners 2 3 in respect of the buildings owned or occupied by them in the Ghantaghar area Scheme, asking them to appear before the Land Acquisition Collector-the 3rd Respondent

facts.text: Serious communal rioting in March 1947 in parts of Punjab, particularly Amritsar, causing extensive damage to property.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the partition of India there were, serious companymunal rioting in March 1947 in some parts of Punjab, particularly in Amritsar These riots as well as those which subsequently took place

facts.text: Punjab Damaged Areas Act 11 of 1947 passed by Governor on 9th May 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Governor of Punjab who had by a proclamation under Sec. 93 of the Govt. of India Act 1935 assuming to himself all powers vested by and under the said Act passed the Punjab Damaged Areas Act 11 of 1947 on 9th May 1947.

facts.text: 1947 Act ceased to have force on 15th August 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of the Governor came to an end on 15th August 1947 and companysequently the 1947 Act would cease to have, force on 15th August 1949.

facts.text: East Punjab Damaged Areas Act 10 of 1949 enacted.

anchor.surface_text: As this. Act would have lapsed by the 15th August 1949, the East Punjab Damaged Areas Act 10 of 1949 was enacted which embodied practically the same provisions

facts.text: Damaged Area Ordinance 16 of 1950 promulgated on 1st December 1950.

anchor.surface_text: had companysequently the Damaged Area Ordinance 16 of 1950 was promulgated by the Governor of Punjab on the 1st December 1950. The Ordinance was replaced by the present Act.

facts.text: Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act 10 of 1951 enacted.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 1 of 1970 filed in original jurisdiction under Art. 32.

issues.text: Whether the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951 (hereinafter called the Act) is violative of Articles 14, 19(1)(f)(g) and 31(2) of the Constitution of India?

anchor.surface_text: challenging the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act 10 of 1951  hereinafter called the Act  as being violative of Art. 14, 19

issues.text: Whether Section 2(d) of the Act offends Article 14 of the Constitution as the definition of 'damaged area' furnishes no guidelines, is arbitrary, unguided, un-canalised, discriminatory, and enables pick and choose, and whether the notification under Section 2(d) is vague?

anchor.surface_text: 1   a  that Sec. 2 d  offends Art. 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as the damaged area as defined under that Section furnishes numberguidelines, is arbitrary, unguided, un-canalised and discriminatory inasmuch- as it enables the State. Government to pick and choose any area and declare it to be damaged area even though it may number at all be damaged while at the same time leaving out other areas similarly situated which are either number damaged or really damaged that in any case the Notification under Sec. 2 d  is vague and therefore bad,

issues.text: Whether the provisions regarding compensation are discriminatory because property can be acquired at the discretion of the Improvement Trust either under the Punjab Town Improvement Act, 1922 or under the Act, with compensation under the former being more advantageous?

anchor.surface_text: b  that the provisions regarding companypensation are also discriminatory because property can be acquired at the discretion of the Improvement Trust either under the Punjab Town Improvement Act 1922 or under the Act even though the companypensation payable under the provision of the former Act are advantageous as companypared to those payable under the Act

issues.text: Whether the compensation provisions in the Act violate Article 31(2) as it stood at the time when the Act was passed in 1951?

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the companypensation provisions in the Act violate Art. 31  2  as it stood at the time when the Act was passed in 1951

issues.text: Whether the impugned notifications sanctioning the two schemes are void because the power of sanction under Section 5 is exhausted after sanctioning the Dharam Singh Market Scheme?

anchor.surface_text: 4  that the impugned Notification sanctioning the two schemes is also void because once the Govt. had exercised the power by sanctioning Dharam Singh Market Scheme, the power ,of sanction under Section 5 is exhausted.

arguments.claim: Test for reasonableness under Art.19: nature of right, purpose, urgency, balanced with social welfare

anchor.surface_text: This Court has in numberuncertain terms laid down the test for ascertaining reasonableness of the restrictions on the rights guaranteed under Art. 19 to be determined by a reference to the nature of the right said to have been infringed, the purpose of the restrictions sought to be imposed, the urgency of the evil and the necessity to rectify or remedy it-all of which has to be balanced with the social welfare or social purpose sought to be achieved.

holdings.text: The provisions of the Act clearly indicate that they are reasonable and are designed to serve the interest of the general public namely to execute schemes in a planned manner for the improvement of the damaged areas of the city of Amritsar. They do not in any way violate the provisions of Art. 19(1)(f)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act it may be noticed clearly indicate that they are reasonable and are designed to serve the interest of the general public namely to execute schemes in a planned manner for the improvement of the damaged areas of the city of Amritsar. They do number in any way violate the provisions of Art. 19 1   f   g .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor reasonableness test under Art.19 considering nature of right, purpose of restriction, urgency, social welfare; opportunities for objections, profit-sharing compensation, appeals ensure balance.

holdings.text: The restrictions imposed by the Act on rights under Art.19(1)(f)(g) are reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has in numberuncertain terms laid down the test for ascertaining reasonableness of the restrictions on the rights guaranteed under Art. 19 to be determined by a reference to the nature of the right said to have been infringed, the purpose of the restrictions sought to be imposed, the urgency of the evil and the necessity to rectify or remedy it-all of which has to be balanced with the social welfare or social purpose sought to be achieved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed Supreme Court precedents on reasonableness test; balanced individual rights against public interest in urban improvement post-riots.

holdings.text: The compensation payable is neither inadequate nor illusory, but on the other hand is not less than the market value and may even be more. There is therefore no violation of Art. 31(2) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: in our view the compensation payable is neither inadequate nor illusory, but on the other hand is not less than the market value and may even be more. There is therefore no violation of Art. 31 2  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compensation = scheme income - costs, minimum market value minus demolition; similar to Land Acquisition Act; profit-sharing ensures adequacy.

holdings.text: Sec. 2(d) is not discriminatory or vague in that it does not indicate the criteria for determining what is a damaged area.

anchor.surface_text: The further contention that Sec. 2 d  is discriminatory of vague in that it does number indicate the criteria for determining what is a damaged area appears to us to be without force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history shows purpose for riot-damaged walled city of Amritsar; entire area qualifies as damaged, notification valid.

holdings.text: If the whole of the walled city of Amritsar is a damaged area, any part thereof is equally a damaged area.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore number difficult to determine what is a damaged area for, if the whole of the walled city of Amritsar is a damaged area, any part thereof is equally a damaged area.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on 1947 riots damaging entire walled city; declaration covers whole, parts included.

holdings.text: There is no justification in the submission that option is given to acquire the area either under the Act or under the Punjab Town Improvement Act according to the discretion of the Trust which is without guidelines and arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: There is however numberjustification in the submission that option is given to acquire the area either under the Act or under the Punjab Town Improvement Act according to the discretion of the Trust which is without guide-lines and arbitrary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sec.3 incorporates PTIA Sec.28 by reference as enabling provision; no discretionary choice between Acts.

holdings.text: Compensation is payable for the buildings also because the definition of land under the Act is comprehensive enough to include buildings.

anchor.surface_text: There is also numbervalidity in the contention that compensation is number payable for the buildings but only for the land because the definition of land under the Act is similar to that under Sec. 3 a  of the Land Acquisition Act and is comprehensive enough to include buildings also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of 'land' mirrors Land Acquisition Act Sec.3(a), includes structures.

holdings.text: None of the objections are sustainable either on the ground of discrimination under Art. 14 or on the schemes being unreasonable or not in the interest of general public violating Art. 19(1)(f)(g) nor on the ground of the compensation payable being inadequate or insufficient so as to infringe the guarantee under Art. 31(2) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: In our view none of the objections are sustainable either on the ground of discrimination under Art. 14 or on the scheme are being unreasonable or number in the interest of general public violating Art. 19  1   f   g  number on the ground of the compensation payable being inadequate or insufficient so as to infringe the guarantee under Art. 31 2  of the Constitution of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of all constitutional challenges after detailed analysis.
